results.title: An Interview with Valda Maskell and Alf
results.creator_credit: Alfred Maskell, Valda Maskell and ACMI
results.brief_description: Valda Maskell, with the assistance of her husband Alfred, gives a touching account of how their love for each other survived World War 2. Valda met Alfred in Bendigo and they managed to get engaged just before Alfred was despatched to Malaya to fight the Japanese. The story is mostly told from Valda’s perspective, how she joined the RAAF and worked there as a cook and how she spent three years working there, all the while knowing nothing of Alfred’s fate. On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

results.title: An Interview with Harry Barkla
results.brief_description: Harry Barkla was part of the 39th Battalion, made up mostly of Chocolate (Chocco) soldiers. They were called this because it was thought that they would melt in the sun, that they wouldn’t know how to fight. In Kokoda, they soon proved themselves and Harry talks about some of the horrific experiences he went through that were typical of this war. These are some of his memories that he has tried to forget but never can. Even if you didn’t know someone’s name in the 39th Battalion, you still called them mate and you never forget your mates.

results.title: An Interview with Arthur Harridge
results.brief_description: Even though Arthur Harridge believes each service being as important as the other, he was primarily an airforce man. He tells of leaving his home and loved ones aboard the Mariposa, bound for the United States and then Europe, where he experienced the horrors of war first hand. An emotional account of the horrors of war, the things that kept the soldiers going returning home and trying to forget.

results.title: An Interview with Alfred Maskell
results.brief_description: Alfred Maskell just wanted to see the world. In 1941, he joined the Australian army and was sent to Malaya. By the time he got there, it was clear the Australian forces were up against it, fighting a strong enemy with weaponry from the previous World War. By the end of the year they were captured by the Japanese and forced to perform many unsavoury tasks, from burying Chinese civilians to working on the Thai-Burma railway and, finally, in Japan where he stayed till the war ended. This is a story of the brutality that many prisoners of war suffered during World War 2.

results.title: Hope
results.creator_credit: Leslie Jones, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Les Jones heard those two magic words “It’s over”, he starting thinking about his future after the war. The middle of three generations of army men, he was part of the last major action in the Pacific part of World War II. As well as being uncertain about his future, Les also thought about those that wouldn’t be returning with him. It is with the thoughts of these lost soldiers in mind, that Les considers war and whether or not there is a better way to solve conflict.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Leslie Jones, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Finding Will
results.creator_credit: Kym Levett, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As the keeper of historical artifacts for his family, Kym Levett recently visited the parts of France that were battlefields during the Great War. He took his two sons and his mission is to find the remains of his great, great Uncle Will Cundy who had died fighting during the war. This is a story of the journey to bring Private William Cundy home.

results.title: Dots and dashes
results.creator_credit: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Catching mumps just before his 18th birthday prevented Kevin Coughlin from joining the RAAF during the second World War. But thanks to his connections, he was able to get work as a Wireless Telegraphist. In the end, Kevin ended up with skills that made him unique. Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jacob Romeril, Kevin Coughlin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.

But thanks to his connections, he was able to get work as a Wireless Telegraphist. In the end, Kevin ended up with skills that made him unique. Naturally left handed, he was forced to tap out morse code with his right hand. This afforded him a dexterity that meant he could do morse code with his right hand and write with his left which made him invaluable. He tells of his time in Darwin and, later, on Peron Island in the Timor Sea.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2009]
results.brief_description: 10 interviews with Victorian war veterans, created as part of the “In our words : Stories from Victorian veterans” Digital Storytelling workshop in August 2009, with the support of the Department of Planning and Community Development, the Shrine of Remembrance, and the Victorian Veterans Council.

results.title: An Interview with Stan Guilfoyle
results.brief_description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.
